avalancheActivity.highlights: The snow is settling in the tawing and gaining strength

snowpackStructure.highlights: Thaw Monday 26.2. affected the snowpack up to ridges and a significant amount of snow was melted. The snowpack became isotherm and refroze again. A little snow has been added since then, and the small wind slabs that may have formed are belived to gone wet and well bounded

travelAdvisory.comment: The temperature has been above freezing, even at higher elevations, causing the snow to settle and become wet. Significant melting of snow has occurred as a result across the country. Over the next few days, temperatures will cool slightly, and we can expect overnight frost and diurnal temperature fluctuations, which should help strengthen the snowpack. Many avalanches released in the East and North of Iceland during the thaw and afterward, due to warming and solar radiation.
travelAdvisory.highlights: Warming across the country since Monday has resulted in numerous avalanches. Cooling weather is expected over the weekend and the snowpack will strengthen as a result of diurnal freeze-thaw cycles.

weatherForecast.highlights: Austlægar áttir og skúrir af og til en bjart á milli. Fremur milt

avalancheActivity.comment: There have been no reports of avalanches since the warming on Monday, March 4th. The avalanches were rather small and stopped in the middle of the slopes. Snow slab avalanches fell in Skálavík on Sunday, March 3rd. Some small loose avalanches occurred on thin layers after the thaw last weekend in Seljalandsdal.
avalancheActivity.highlights: A significant amount of snow has melted in the recent warm weather, and measurements indicate that the snowpack has become isothermal in many mountainous areas. It can be expected to further strengthen with overnight frost in the coming days.

snowpackStructure.highlights: A significant amount of snow has melted during this week"s warm weather, and temperatures have been above freezing both in the mountains and in low-lying areas since Monday. Snow stakes indicate that the snowpack has generally reached isothermal conditions after the warmth. It can be expected that it will further consolidate in the cooling weather and overnight frost in the coming days.

weatherForecast.highlights: Hæglætisveður yfir helgina, lægir aðfaranótt laugardags, milt í veðri og úrkomulítið næstu daga.

avalancheActivity.comment: Several small avalanches, minor slabs, and loose snow avalanches released on SE aspects on Sunday and Monday during warming. On Saturday, a roughly 50-meter wide slab released on a steep S aspect in Upsadal above Dalvík, likely triggered by snowmobile activity. Several more avalanches occurred over the weekend, at least one of which was human-triggered.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The snowpack has strengthened considerably in the area after prolonged warming up in the mountains since Monday. Overnight frost during the weekend will further strengthen the snow. Instability was found in older wind slabs last weekend and this weakness is likely still present higher up in the mountains.

snowpackStructure.highlights: The snowpack has strengthened following persistent warmth in the mountains since Monday. Instability was found in wind slabs last weekend, and this weakness may still persist at higher elevations. Weak layers developed due to high-temperature gradient observed in snow pits over the weekend in Siglufjordur, indicating significant instability and propagation with very little stress on the interface of firn and wind slab. Now, with warming this week in the mountains, there has been considerable instability and several minor slab avalanches. Snow has strengthened throughout the week and will likely further strengthen with overnight frost during the weekend. Expect weaknesses to persist in higher elevations and inland on Tröllaskagi.

travelAdvisory.comment: The temperature has been above freezing, even at higher elevations, causing the snow to settle and become wet. Over the next few days, temperatures will cool slightly, and we can expect overnight frost and diurnal temperature fluctuations, which should help strengthen the snowpack. Many avalanches released in the East and North of Iceland during the thaw and afterward, due to warming and solar radiation.

weatherForecast.highlights: Hæglætisveður, úrkomulaust og næturfrost um helgina.

avalancheActivity.comment: Rather small slab avalanches released 6th March due to solar radiation in highest mountains in Fjarðarheiði and around Seyðisfjörður. When temperature rose on Monday several avalanches released in the forecasting area. Off piste skiers triggered three slab avalanches on March 2nd, both in Stafdalur and Oddsskarð.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Snow has become wet and subsided in the last few days in thaw and rain. Unstable windslabs can be found in highest mountains. Skiers triggered avalanches last weekend and many natural avalanches released during the week. Snow is becoming more stable in colder weather.

snowpackStructure.highlights: Unstable windslabs can persist in high elevations, rather thin in most places but can be thicker in gullies. Below 700 m elevation snow has become wet in thaw and rain in the last few days. Older snow is considered more stable. Some layering persists in the snowpack, as seen in a snowpit in Oddsskarð March 5th, with BRK fracture at CT11. Snow is becoming more stable in colder weather.

travelAdvisory.comment: The temperature has been above freezing, even at higher elevations, causing the snow to settle and become wet. weatherForecast.highlights: Suðaustan og sunnan áttir næstu daga, og stöku skúrir eða él. Kólnandi veður.
